question0.questionText: Do you have a case pending?
helperText: "Pending" refers to any case that is pending or has not been fully resolved. For example, if a case does not have a case disposition, it is likely a case pending.

question1.questionText: Are you sealing a conviction or a non-conviction?
helperText: "Convicted" refers to the judgment (sentence) on a verdict or a finding of guilty, a plea of guilty or a plea of nolo contendere, or a plea or verdict of not guilty by reason of insanity.

question2.questionText: Is this an eligible misdemeanor/felony or an ineligible misdemeanor/felony?

question3.questionText: Have you subsequently been convicted of another crime in any jurisdiction?

question4.questionText: Has it been 8 years since you were off papers?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

question5.questionText: Is your non-conviction the result of a Deferred Sentencing Agreement?

question6.questionText: Do you also have an ineligible conviction on your record?

question7.questionText: Do you also have an ineligible conviction on your record?

question8.questionText: Is the non-conviction for an eligible misdemeanor or an ineligible misdemeanor/felony?

question9.questionText: Was the case terminated before charging by the prosectution (no papered)?

question10.questionText: Has it been 4 years since you were "off papers" for the felony non-conviction?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

question11.questionText: Has it been 3 years since you were "off papers" for the felony non-conviction?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

question12.questionText: Has it been two years since you were "off papers" for the misdemeanor non-conviction?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

question13.questionText: Is the ineligible conviction for a felony or misdemeanor?

question14.questionText: Has it been 10 years since you were "off papers" for the misdemeanor conviction?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

question15.questionText: Has it been 5 years since you were "off papers" for the misdemeanor conviction?
helperText: "Off papers" means when a person has been unconditionally discharged from incarceration, commitment, probation, parole or supervised release – whichever is the latest.

questionA1.questionText: Were you arrested in DC because you had a warrant in another jurisdiction (i.e. another state)?

questionA2.questionText: Have you appeared before the proper authority in the jurisdiction that issued the warrant?

questionA3.questionText: Can you prove that you appeared before the proper authority in the jurisdiction that issued the warrant?

questionB1.questionText: Does your criminal record incorrectly identify you as having a case or arrest that you did not have?
helperText: (For example – Someone used your name when they were arrested or a data entry error has linked your name or other identifying information to a case that is not yours)

questionB2.questionText: Have you checked with the United States Attorney’s Office to see if fingerprints are on file for the individual at was actually arrested?

questionC1.questionText: Were you arrested for or charged with crime but "not convicted" of that crime as defined below?
helperText: "Not convicted" means (a) the prosecutor did not paper or did not charge the case; OR (b) the prosecutor dropped the charges against the you before trial; OR  (c) the court dismissed the charges against the you; OR (d) you were acquitted (found “not guilty”) of the crime after a trial.

questionC2.questionText: Are you willing to swear under oath that you are actually innocent of the crime for which you were arrested or charged?
helperText: Please Note: False swearing can be prosecuted as a crime.

questionC3.questionText: Can you prove that the offense for which you were arrested or charged did not occur?

questionC4a.questionText: Can you prove that you did not commit the offense for which you were arrested or charged?

questionC4b.questionText: Can you prove that you did not commit the offense for which you were arrested or charged?

questionC5.questionText: Based on your responses, you may not be able to file for sealing under Actual Innocence.  Please see the "Non-Conviction, Eligible Misdemeanor (16- 803(a))" tab on the home page for an additional option

questionD1.questionText: Were you arrested for or charged with crime but "not convicted" of that crime as defined below?
helperText: "Not convicted" means (a) the prosecutor did not paper or did not charge the case; OR (b) the prosecutor dropped the charges against the you before trial; OR  (c) the court dismissed the charges against the you; OR (d) you were acquitted (found “not guilty”) of the crime after a trial.

questionD2.questionText: Was the crime one of the misdemeanors listed below?
helperText: Please Note: False swearing can be prosecuted as a crime.

questionD3.questionText: Do you have other arrests or charges for additional crimes that you are trying to seal and/or a conviction for a felony?

questionE1.questionText: Were you arrested for or charged with crime but "not convicted" of that crime as defined below?
helperText: "Not convicted" means (a) the prosecutor did not paper or did not charge the case; OR (b) the prosecutor dropped the charges against the you before trial; OR  (c) the court dismissed the charges against the you; OR (d) you were acquitted (found “not guilty”) of the crime after a trial.

questionE2.questionText: Is the offense that you were arrested or charged with a felony OR listed below?

questionE3.questionText: Were you arrested and charged with the crime?

answers.answerText: I was only arrested (case was "not papered")
I was arrested and charged with the crime (case was "papered")

questionE4.questionText: Do you have other arrests or charges for additional crimes that you are trying to seal and/or a conviction for a felony?

questionF1.questionText: Were you convicted of a crime as defined above?
helperText: Generally, "convicted" means that you were found guilty after a trial, pled guilty, or pled nolo contendere ("no contest") to the charges. A Youth Act sentence that was not "set aside" IS a conviction also.  It is also a conviction if you were found not guilty by reason of insanity.

questionF2.questionText: Is the crime for which you were convicted listed below?

questionF3.questionText: Were you convicted of a felony?

questionF4.questionText: Was the felony charge for your failure to appear in court (Felony BRA)?

questionF5.questionText: Was the felony charge for your failure to appear in court (Felony BRA)?

questionF6.questionText: Is this your only conviction on your criminal record?

questionF7.questionText: Do you have other arrests or charges for additional crimes that you are trying to seal and/or a conviction for a felony?
